Award.AwardTitle: Understanding changing ENSO flavors in the mid-Holocene laboratory.
Award.AbstractNarration:
El Ni単o/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) events can have profound impacts on regional climate in many parts of the world. Recent studies have shown that two primary "flavors" of El Ni単o exist, with distinct intensities and sea-surface temperature (SST) patterns: the Eastern Pacific El Ni単o, which is more intense, with warmer SSTs concentrated in the eastern Pacific; and the Central Pacific El Ni単o, which is more moderate, with warmer SSTs concentrated in the central Pacific. Neither models nor observations conclusively indicate which of these ENSO flavors will be dominant as greenhouse gas warming progresses, creating uncertainty in projections of regional climate change throughout the Pacific basin. To help address this uncertainty, a team of scientists from the University of Hawaii will undertake a paleoclimate reconstruction study focusing on understanding the response of ENSO flavors to climate conditions in the mid-Holocene (approximately 5000-7000 years before present). Through a synthesis of climate model results and paleoclimate proxies, the project will investigate the origin of ENSO flavors and their sensitivity to changes in tropical climate. In addition, modeling experiments will be performed to examine the role of stochastic noise in ENSO response to climate change.

This research will advance the understanding of ENSO behavior under past climate conditions, leading to better-constrained models of future climate change in the tropics. The project will support two early-career scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The El Niño/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) phenomenon has profound impacts on weather, public health, fisheries productivity, coral reef health, crop yield, and the economy worldwide. El Niño has been shown to have different “flavors”, i.e. diverse magnitudes and spatial pattern of sea surface temperature anomalies. The Eastern Pacific (EP) ENSO flavor is characterized by peak sea surface temperature anomalies in the eastern Pacific (e.g. 1997-98), while in the Central Pacific (CP) flavor anomalies peak in the central Pacific (e.g. 2004-05). However, whether these “flavors” are distinct modes of the system dominated by different physical mechanisms, or they are samples of a “continuum” remains an open question which affects our understanding and forecasting of El Niño. The instrumental record, due to its short length, may be inadequate to answer these questions. Climate models disagree on potential future changes in ENSO flavors, and the scientific community is seeking to reduce this uncertainty and constrain future climate model projections. Paleoclimate proxies offer an extension of the instrumental record, and provide a benchmark for evaluating climate models.

One well-documented past climate is the midHolocene (~4-7,000 years ago); the primary forcing of climate in this period is precessional, leading to altered annual cycle of tropical Pacific sea surface temperatures. Paleoclimate evidence from the eastern tropical Pacific suggests a significant suppression of ENSO activity during the mid-Holocene, while fossil coral records from the central Pacific indicate that the mid-Holocene decrease in ENSO activity is not significant compared to other Holocene time intervals. Using quantitative model-proxy comparison methods and a set of climate model simulations, this project showed that a potential explanation for mid-Holocene changes in proxy variance across the Pacific consistent with ENSO dynamical analysis is a differential response of ENSO flavors to midHolocene climate forcing; in particular, a significant reduction of EP ENSO variance and a slight increase in CP ENSO variance.  

New General Circulation Model (GCM) experiments, as well as simulations with less complex ENSO models, indicate that the relative response of ENSO flavors to changes in the annual cycle of sea surface temperatures in the tropical Pacific is antisymmetric. In particular, a strengthening of the annual cycle leads to strengthening of the EP ENSO flavor in boreal winter and a weakening of the CP ENSO flavor, and the opposite is true for weakening of the annual cycle. The relationship between the magnitude of the annual cycle and the relative frequency of the two ENSO flavors in past climates that this project revealed illustrates that disagreements in potential changes in the tropical Pacific annual cycle among GCMs may affect their projections of future changes in ENSO flavors and their impacts.

This project further investigated the impact of the two ENSO flavors in three regions in the western, central and eastern Pacific using paleoclimate records, instrumental observations, and high-resolution atmospheric circulation models. First, we investigated ENSO-related signals in a tree ring record of Javanese teak (western Pacific), and found that CP ENSO has a clear influence on precipitation, while EP ENSO does not. Second, we analyzed Hawaiian precipitation, and showed that the perception that El Niño events are associated with drought conditions in the state of Hawaii is only true for EP ENSO events. On the contrary, CP events lead to state-wide wetter conditions except in high elevations.  This study is a first look at the impacts of the two ENSO flavors on Hawaiian rainfall and illustrates their differences; given the uncertainty in projected changes in the two flavors, these differences should be taken into consideration by decision-makers and managers planning for future climate change adaptation and mitigation in the Islands. Last, we employed a high-resolution weather forecasting model to investigate the impact of ENSO flavors in a region of high-elevation lakes in the Ecuadorian Andes (eastern Pacific). The results show that precipitation during EP events in this region is mostly convective in contrast to primarily non-convective precipitation during CP events. This analysis sheds light into the uncertainties surrounding the interpretation of lake sediment records from the eastern Pacific, and supports the hypothesis that paleoclimate records from this region may be recording a differential response of ENSO flavors to past climate forcings.

This project was interdisciplinary in nature, and provided both the paleoclimate and climate dynamics community with tools and insights to better understand the nature and origins of ENSO flavors, and their sensitivity to external forcings of climate. It trained two early-career scientists and a student from underrepresented groups in STEM. The project was developed at the University of Hawaii, which is a designated minority-serving institution. The PI and co-PIs are actively engaged in collaborative and independent teaching, have developed new courses, participated in numerous research, outreach in local TV stations and service activities, and built their research teams which comprise a diverse consortium of students and postdocs, including two female PhD students.
